'Dobu Island' is an island, part of D'Entrecasteaux Islands in Papua New Guinea.
It is located south of Fergusson Island and north of Normanby Island.

The people of Dobu were the subject of a seminal anthropological study by Reo
Fortune. He described the Dobuan character as "paranoid", obsessed with black
magic, and as having extremely unusual attitudes toward sex and violence.

Fortune's account was reiterated by Ruth Benedict in her popular work Patterns
of Culture. However, many later anthropologists expressed skepticism. Ann
Chowning, review of Fortune's Sorcerers of Dobu, American Anthropologist, New
Series, Vol. 66, No. 2 (Apr., 1964), pp. 455-457

Fortune's analysis was significantly challenged by Susanne Kuehling in her
2005 title Dobu: Ethics of Exchange on a Massim Island, Papua New Guinea. In
particular, Kuehling's interest lies at the intersection of ethics and
personal conduct.
